The day is really to be deemed a pause in time's serious flight, when folly could with propriety travesty wisdom, and set the world smiling. For one Ja 'I thing, this fateful day of mirth and mystery is the first of the autumn and winter holidays, and yet more significant, it is for the young folks the first break in the school year. With al its festivities are for the most part reserved for the period after nightfall, so that even the Individuals who are occupied during the day .may participate. The festival of the night of October 31 is in Its origin and traditions one of the most pic turesque which now finds observance in this country. It has a number of different designa tions, among which are Hallowe’en, All Hallow Even. Nutcrack Night and Snap Apple Night. It derives it most common name, however, as the eve or vigil of All Saints’ or All Hallows Day i November 1). From time out of mind this has been heralded as a night when witches, devils and other michief-makers are abroad on their baneful midnight errands, while the fairies are supposed to hold on that night a grand anniversary. To accept the spirit of the season the de votee of Hallowe’en must concede that on no other night of the year do such supernatural Influences prevail as after dark on the closing day of October. According to ancient beliefs the spirits of the dead then wander about- and iu some instances the spirits of liyipg persons are supposed to have the temporary power to leave their bodies and join the ghostly throng. BUT DON'T THROW FLOUR Within reasonable bounds Washingtonians?youngsters and their elders i alike?will be permitted to enjoy all the Halloween revelry they like tonight. Orders to the police department prohibit roughness, rowdyism and vandalism, but permit all the harmless fun that can be extracted from the night when witches, warlocks, imps, gnomes, ghosts and all the denizens of the unseen world become visible for a few hours. Just the same, it will be as well for householders to take in the porch furniture, put the rubber plant in a place of safety, fasten an anchor to the garbage can and generally nail down all movable articles that might tempt the prowling spooks. Efficient as the members of the police force may try to be, it is a physical impossibility for a few hundred men to cover the entire city and head off the mischievous pranks of small or larger?boys bent on giving Halloween at least a resemblance to the Halloweens of former years. Of course, the mischievous youth who find fun in pi-ing a whole neighborhood isn't going to abandon the nefarious practice altogether, no matter wnat oraers j>iaj. runmati may nave given his men; they are going to take chances even if they know a trip to a police station is the penalty of being caught. So, householders, safety first! All Virginia to Celebrate. The big Halloween celebration, however, is to be held across the Potomac, and the whole state of Virginia is to be the scene of the revelry. Whistles are to blow, bells are to ring, bonfires are to blaze, praise and thanksgiving meetings are to be held in hundreds of churches, speeches are to be made and the evening is to be given up to general jollification. Because the stroke of midnight tonight is to be the death knell of "the Demon Rum." At 12 o'clock tonight King Alcohol becomes an outlaw in the Old Dominion, and Virginia's sons and daughters are going to celebrate the event. Today the saloons and liquor stores in Virginia are legal, licensed establishments; tomorrow they are to be 1 proscribed. At practically all the clubs in Alexandria city and county elaborate preparations have been made for fitting observance of the two events, Halloween and the dawning aridness of the whole state. It is whispered that guest cards, "just for tonight," have been at a premium for the last week or so, many, very many, Washingtonians desiring to be in at the death and to do their bit toward putting down King Alcohol. Of course, the usual Halloween features have been provided at the clubs, but it is expected that, along with the j other spooks and spirits, spirits fru- j menti will be featured for what is an- j nounced as "positively the final ap- j pearance before any Virginia audi- j ence." Alexandria has planned for a city- I wide celebration, in which Halloween and the demise of the saloon business are to be celebrated jointly. In an- i ticipation of possible disorders, the po- lice force has received orders to be on the job early, and remain until late, because, while it isn't at all likely the Virginia lawmakers gave a thought to Halloween when they fixed the day and hour for the ending of the liquor business in the state, the conjunction is too good to miss, and it is to be expected that many will not overlook the opportunity for indulging in more or less rowdyism.
